newsitem.title: GERMANY: Munich Re sees Amer Re merger hurting 97 earnings.
newsitem.headline: Munich Re sees Amer Re merger hurting 97 earnings.

text.p: German reinsurance giant Munich Re said on Wednesday its mega-takeover of American Re would pressure its earnings next year but should yield a positive impact on its results from 1998.

"One and one will not make two in this case, but three," Munich Re management board chairman Hans-Juergen Schinzler told the Boersen Zeitung daily newspaper, referring to his hopes for the merged operations.

Muenchener Rueckversicherungs AG, known as Munich Re, revealed its plans to spend $3.3 billion on third-ranked U.S. non-life reinsurer American Re last month, in a bid to boost its share of the world's biggest insurance market.
Schinzler told the newspaper that the merger would hurt Munich Re's earnings in 1997 but that synergy effects would kick in to improve the group's earnings per share in 1998.
The move would be a "quantum leap" for Munich Re's U.S. business, which has been relatively underdeveloped so far.

The Munich Re chief said he was convinced that American Re had smoothed out longstanding difficulties in its liability cover which helped cause it a net loss of $87.6 million in 1995. He said the U.S. group was expected to post net profit of around $200 million on 1996 business.
Schinzler also said he was confident that the takeover would be completed by year-end. Although he hoped for a 100 percent takeover, a full acquisition was not essential.
Munich Re's $65 per share offer for American Re is backed by the U.S. firm's 64-percent owner, investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co (KKR).
Schinzler said his strategy for now would be to keep Munich Re's dividend on hold after several years of increasing payouts.

Although full results for its 1995/1996 business year are not yet available, Munich Re has already said its net profit in the period exceeded the previous year's 325 million marks ($219 million) and raised its dividend to 16 marks from 13.50.

Schinzler made no specific forecasts on the impact of the merger on earnings. When the deal was announced, the Bavarian-based giant said American Re would increase its premium income from reinsurance to 22.5 billion marks and its overall income to 37 billion marks.
Schinzler added there were "no viable possibilities" at present for any futher takeovers in the reinsurance industry.
Munich Re's merger with American Re, the latest in a series of shake-outs in the industry, has sparked much talk of more consolidation to come.
